statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Oregon 94, USC 87 (OT)
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- The Oregon Ducks still have a fighting chance to make it to the Pac-10 Tournament. The USC Trojans squandered their final opportunity to stay alive. Bryce Taylor had 23 points and Maarty Leunen scored five of his seven points in the final 57.1 seconds of overtime, leading Oregon to a 94-87 victory over USC on Thursday night. The Ducks, who began their centennial season with a 9-1 record, have to beat UCLA on Saturday at Pauley Pavilion in their regular-season finale to qualify for a return trip to Los Angeles -- where eight teams will vie for an automatic NCAA berth. "Our destiny is in L.A. -- like it has been the past four years," Oregon coach Ernie Kent said. "We need to beat UCLA. We want to go in the front door of the tournament and not worry about going in the back door. We'll take the back door, but we want the front door." Malik Hairston scored 19 points for Oregon (14-12, 6-11 Pac-10). Aaron Brooks, whose career-high 34 points against the Trojans in the Ducks' victory at Eugene on New Year's Eve equaled the most by any sophomore in school history, finished with 14. Oregon's 94 points was its highest total of the season. The Trojans (11-17, 4-12) have lost eight of their last 10 games, and will miss the Pac-10 tournament for the first time in the eight seasons it has been held. What makes it even more frustrating for the Trojans is that the tournament will take place a couple of miles up Figueroa Street at Staples Center. Nick Young scored 21 points and Rory O'Neil had 17 for the Trojans, who are 9-15 under interim coach Jim Saia since the firing of Henry Bibby on Dec. 6. Saia will relinquish the head coaching duties to Tim Floyd on April 1. "This epitomizes our season," Saia said after the Trojans' first overtime game of the campaign. "The kids battled every game and I did the best I could as a coach. We were in a position to win a lot of these games, but we just don't know how to win down the stretch. I know we haven't won a lot of games, but you can't say it wasn't entertaining basketball." Oregon has beaten USC six straight times, including the title game of the 2003 Pac-10 tournament. It's the second-longest winning streak for the Ducks against the Trojans since the schools began playing each other in 1956. Oregon beat them nine straight times between 1987 and 1991, including an opening-round matchup in the '87 Pac-10 tournament. Leunen gave Oregon an 87-84 lead with a 3-pointer, then added two free throws 20 seconds later. Young's 3-pointer cut the margin to two with 24.2 seconds left, but USC's Gregg Guenther missed a short baseline jumper with 13.2 seconds to go after Oregon's Chamberlain Oguchi made one of two from the line. The Ducks put it away with two free throws each from Brooks and Oguchi for the final margin, matching their biggest lead of the game. USC trailed by five points in the final two minutes of regulation before Young hit a 12-foot jumper that got a friendly bounce off the rim and missed the ensuing free throw trying for the three-point play. But O'Neil tipped in Young's miss, cutting Oregon's lead to 76-75 with 1:41 left. Brooks made one of two at the line for the Ducks, and Young's two free throws tied it at 77-all with 40.4 seconds left. The Ducks called a timeout with 27 seconds left to set up a play, but Mitch Platt threw up an 18-foot airball with 5.1 seconds on the clock. The Trojans inbounded after a timeout and Gabriel Pruitt dribbled the length of the court for an apparent game-winning layup, but was called for an offensive charge by referee Kevin Brill and fouled out after running into Leunen with 1.5 seconds left. "Kevin Brill is a good official. He made the call he thought was right, so I can't get mad at Kevin," Saia said. "It probably was a good call, but I would have liked to get that call at home. I thought we won the game -- not to mention that it fouled Pruitt out of the overtime." The Trojans had a slightly easier time in the paint against Oregon than they did the last time the Ducks visited the L.A. Sports Arena, when 7-foot center Ian Crosswhite had 22 points and a career-high 13 rebounds in Oregon's 92-74 victory Crosswhite was suspended for the rest of this season on Feb. 9 for violating Athletic Department policy. Oregon is 3-4 without him.
